results.title: Insect collecting
results.creator_credit: Pat Dowling Pictures and Pat Dowling
results.brief_description: How an insect collection can be established. Representative terrestial and aquatic insects are studied in extreme close-up photography, collecting methods shown include netting, beating host plants, night collecting, investigating dead trees, using the Beriese funnel to procure microscopic speciments, and aquatic methods.

results.title: Insearch of viewable objects
results.creator_credit: Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School and Jane Nicholls
results.brief_description: Traces the life of the voyeur, showing the pleasure, pain and confusion. This is a student film which explores the main character’s voyeuristic experiences from boyhood to manhood who, eventually has the cameras turned on him at the end of the film - the “watcher” has now become the “watched”! Cinematography by John Tweg.

results.title: Insatiable
results.brief_description: A stylised, abstract musical narrative working around ideas of “performance”. Four singers who arrive at an old theatre for an audition. As they wait their turn to be called to perform, the singers gradually reveal through songs more about their pasts and speculate on their possible futures.

results.title: Insan = Human being
results.creator_credit: S C Cinema and Ibrahim Shaddad
results.brief_description: This experimental film without dialogue makes innovative use of sound to tell the story of a shepherd who, having lost his wife, children and cattle after his homeland is stricken by drought, goes to the city to find work. Through a poetic association of images the film critiques the dehumanising effects on the Sudanese people of the Sharia ruled government that was in power in the early eighties.

results.title: Innocent strangers
results.creator_credit: United Nations Television, Joe O'Brien and Jose Quijano
results.brief_description: A short television film featuring refugee stories from various parts of the world including the plight of 1,000,000 in Palestine. The film was originally produced by the United Nations Office of Public Information World Refugee Year. Narrated by Ralph Bellamy.

results.title: Innocence unprotected = Nevinost bez zastite
results.creator_credit: Avala Film, Bosko Savic and Dusan Makavejev
results.brief_description: The first all-Serbian talkie feature rescued from oblivion by Makavejev was made in 1942 during the Nazi Occupation, a naive melodrama in which a strong man (played by the filmmaker, a real life strong man-cum-Houdini type) rescues the heroine from a lecher and a wicked stepmother. It was banned by the Occupation government for attracting local audiences away from more sophisticated German fare, then denounced after the war for being German-inspired. Makavejev colour tinted the footage to highlight its folk charm. Through a dialectical approach to montage he provides an ironic commentary on the themes of innocence and time by intercutting the fictional footage, interviews with members of the original production and wartime newsreels. In Serbo-Croatian with English subtitles. Cast includes Ivanka Vukasovic, Dragoljub Gojkovic Beli and Miodrag Petrovic Sarlo. Note: Original film directed by Dragolyub Aleksic.

results.title: Innocence
results.creator_credit: Strand, New Oz Productions, Premium Movie Partnership, South Australian Film Corporation, Cinemedia Corporation, Paul Cox and Mark Patterson
results.brief_description: Paul Cox’s “Innocence” is a tender meditation on life and love at old age. Charles “Bud” Tingwell plays Andreas, an elderly widow who is undergoing a reflective period in his life marked by clarity and melancholy. A sentimental, rather impetuous man, Andreas longs for the woman he had a fleeting though passionate affair with over 40 years ago. “Innocence” begins with the re-encounter of Andreas and Claire (Julia Blake) and traces their flowering love and deep mutual affection. It’s a reunion that reawakens a love which has laid dormant for many years and that turns them both into young lovers: they become nervous before their first sexual encounter; they long for each other’s company at every moment afterward. In fact, their love is like a ‘time travel’ experience with flashbacks emphasising the entwinement of past and present. It is rare to see a film so devoted to the elderly and their affairs of the heart. Cox also manages to outline the complexities involved. For example, Claire’s new love poses serious problems for her marriage, and forces both herself and her husband, John (Terry Norris), to question their 45-year commitment. “Innocence” is ultimately a story about love, its different forms, its both destructive potential and ecstatic power.

results.title: Inner Rhythm
results.brief_description: This documentary goes behind the scenes to discover the relationship between a composer and a choreographer. John Lang, Ahmed Hassen, Robert Desrosiers and the National Ballet of Canada are featured.

results.title: Inner city, by West Coast artist Michael McMillen: a film
results.brief_description: The neglected exterior quality of Inner City is an environmental sculpture which takes us to the veiled border between illusion and reality. Michael McMillen began building Inner City in 1975, finishing it in Nov 1977 for the opening of his one-man exhibition at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art.

results.title: Inland with Sturt
results.creator_credit: Australian National Film Board, Shan Benson and Hugh McInnes
results.brief_description: The historic journey of explorer Charles Sturt down the Murrumbidgee and Murray Rivers opened up one of the world’s most prosperous fruit and cereal growing areas. The re-enactment of the trip by a group of young Australians, as recorded in this film, was one of the highlights of the Australian Commonwealth Jubilee Celebrations.
